data.text: Are There Any Challenges of Solo Bicycle Touring?
Hello guys, what's your experience with solo ride travels? Any challenges?
Going solo removes all the challenges. It’s just you going where you want at your pace. The world is your oyster solo.
data.author: Doug Westcott

data.text: Currently touring through Poland solo. There are one concern and one problem: concern: what, if you have an accident. No one can help you immediately. Problem so far: language barriers.
data.author: Rene We

data.text: In the unlikely event that an accident occurs. Now that's a concern
data.author: Ortiz

data.text: indeed
data.author: Rene We

data.text: Only 'challenge' is shopping
data.author: Muriel Zaccuri

data.text: Your insecurity?

data.text: In situations of accidents

data.text: I've manages a few multi-month tours in multiple countries..
data.author: Robert Clark

data.text: Share some tips

data.text: Born an Only Child, No siblings..
data.author: Robert Clark

data.text: accidents are rare. Ride cautiously.
data.author: Andrea Collisson

data.text: Thank you
data.author: Ortiz

data.text: I did my solo through Spain and Portugal..no problem. Having someone take some pics of me riding would have been nice... just that
data.author: Leslie Carvery

data.text: I guess the locals were friendly
data.author: Ortiz

data.text: yes

data.text: I'm planning for my first solo ride before the end of the year
data.author: Ortiz

data.text: I got out early..April I flew to Lisbon rode 6 weeks
data.author: Leslie Carvery

data.text: I salute you. You're very strong
data.author: Ortiz

data.text: thank you. It was an amazing experience.
data.author: Leslie Carvery

data.text: Just cycled 1000km from London to Heidelberg solo. As others say you pick your own pace and rest points which is great. Just remember you need to be able to fix mechanicals on your own
data.author: Sam Minett-Smith

data.text: Very important
data.author: Ortiz

data.text: Solo is the only way for me. Tried dual rides but it never worked out. Maybe if you are a couple or riding on a tandem. That worked for me but my partner died too early.
data.author: Jörg Duurkoop

data.text: Always have some kind of backup plan. I was on a short tour and broke my ankle. I had a large ebike, usually i use a gravel bike, and a trailer. Luckily being not more than 100 miles from home I was able to finally get someone to get me. However, I had to wait a week out in camp with a broken ankle before someone could get me.
data.author: Gerald Raton

data.text: Sounds scary. Hope you got home at last
data.author: Ortiz

data.text: whaaaat a week? You need better friends in my opinion. Any of my friends would drop what they were doing snd rescue me.
data.author: Arturo Tinio Alindada

data.text: How do you get real friends ?
data.author: Ortiz

data.text: lol, I am kind of a loner and no real friends.
data.author: Gerald Raton

data.text: you start with being a real friend to those who share the same values as you.
data.author: Arturo Tinio Alindada

data.text: I cycled all over the world for several years. About 80% of it was solo. It's easier to travel solo than it is with others but it's also fun to share the journey. No discussion about what to do, just choose. Stop early, ride late, stay an extra day, you can do whatever you want without needing to take others opinions into consideration.
data.author: Jacob Ashton

data.text: If I was with you, all that would have been possible cuz I am easy, lol
data.author: Arturo Tinio Alindada

data.text: You deal with any challenge alone. So if you are scared you are scared alone… that was my biggest challenge. Had to bike through a wildfire and had to call mom🙈 And you always eat alone so you have to be comfertable going out alon. And you do aaaaall the research alone which can be pretty timeconsuming🥵
data.author: Anne Bryn

data.text: I don't mind doing it alone. I'm kinda an introvert 😁
data.author: Ortiz

data.text: that’s good😇 I mean you also find people on the way which is good. I’ve only had 3-4 days on my trip of sofar 50day trip where I though it would have been nice to have someone to lean on… and was a bit scared or worried🙈 Mostly I prefere the freedom that traveling alone gives. People can be very exhausting if you are around them 24/7😂
data.author: Anne Bryn

data.text: lol. Kinda weird because most ladies I've interacted with are scared of doing it alone
data.author: Ortiz

data.text: challenging
data.author: Erick HR

data.text: well described.
data.author: Rene We

data.text: #independantWoman 😉
data.author: Anne Bryn

data.text: I like it
data.author: Ortiz

data.text: I have done most of my cycle touring solo. Generally preferred for reasons already mentioned. They outweigh benefits of cycling with others. That said depending on type of person you are you may get lonely without person to share with. I found exploring and learning (and being dead tired most nights) that never was a factor for me. However if you feel it might then make sure you stay at some hostels along way just to meet people and have chats about your adventures (and theirs). Either do it whole trip or if wild camping just do it every now and then. Or even meet up with other cyclist doing same leg of journey every now and then. But I have a feeling if you are wondering about it you will be completely fine doing solo.
data.author: Duane Taylor

data.text: Best way to explore the world 😃
data.author: Konrad Przyłucki

data.text: Since my retirement in 2014 I have done numerous tours around Europe alone, totaling about 34'000 km and it has always been wonderful. Of course, as a solo traveler, you don't have to be afraid and also be a little fatal, because it is not possible without unexpected challenges of all kinds.
data.author: Hans Weber

data.text: I've been solo traveling for 40 years. Sept to May in the USA.
data.author: Gary Palmer

data.text: With all of the modern communication devices, Facebook and such you are never really alone.
data.author: Kerry Vanderzalm

data.text: I can relate
data.author: Ortiz

data.text: true dat
data.author: Arturo Tinio Alindada

data.text: The Ultimate "ME" TIME
data.author: Atrez

data.text: Recently finished a 4,500 solo tour with no problem at all and actually look for desolate and remote routes. I’m pretty comfortable with myself!
data.author: Omare War

data.text: Always😃
data.author: Anders Hansen

data.text: Solo is great because you are more approachable by strangers. You met so many locals and offers of a meal and accomodation.
data.author: Graeme de Wit

data.text: Whixh side of the world do they offer free food 😂
data.author: Ortiz

data.text: ha ha , if you come to South Africa it will be every day. One time for a week , every day a couple would pass me and would then be waiting at the next available place. They would have tea and biscuits waiting.
data.author: Graeme de Wit

data.text: The biggest challenge I found was to limit my daily mileage. Because I was alone, the thought of spending long hours alone in a campsite kept me on the saddle and doing many more miles than I wanted to do.
data.author: Mick Dolan

data.text: this is a sad observation isn’t it? if I met a solo biker anywhere that needed a place to stay, I would not think twice - id tell him to move on, lol. No, I would invite him in for the night, a warm meal and a bed even to rest on
data.author: Arturo Tinio Alindada

data.text: I'd say it depends where you are travelling. The only real issue is security when you go shopping. Leaving your bike outside a shop is risky in some parts of the world.
data.author: Tony Gahegan

data.text: Definitely best way to travel..and best way to meet people
data.author: Tina Brocklebank

data.text: Only yourself to worry about and I generally find that if I ride with a group I end up troubleshooting for everyone 👍👍
data.author: Guy Burton

data.text: no
data.author: Xander Gisbey

data.text: Challenges only with sickness or injury. But as long as you are in civilized/populated areas, those challenges are manageable.
data.author: Axel Knobbe

data.text: I always thought most people ride alone
data.author: Jenni Tuomivaara

data.text: Have you ever done it?
data.author: Ortiz

data.text: Yes most of the times alone.
data.author: Jenni Tuomivaara

data.text: I imagine pedaling is hard . But this group is REALLY making me want to try it. 😂 You lot are so inspiring!!
data.author: Alan Law

data.text: The camino de Santiago, it was not a long ride but 10 days cycling alone, was one of the best expirience of my life.
data.author: Frank Salterberg

data.text: The only stressful part was loading my bike and panniers on and off trains by myself. You have to take the panniers off usually, so where do you put them while taking your bike on the train. They are left on the busy platform and there often is a time crunch to get your gear on or off.
data.author: Rhonda Klann Leduc

data.text: I just had to laugh at this one Rhonda. I have just now literally staggered home with my bike bagged up ready to catch train tomorrow. Via Italian internal trains, bikes still have to be bagged, so whilst I can cycle onto train from Geneva to Milan, I had to have the bike fully bagged from Milan to Florence. And it’s gonna be fun lugging the dismantled bike plus the two panniers on and of etc. However as other posts say David O’Donnell the serious upside of this is that you meet gorgeous people like Benjamin and Ernest at Decathalon in Geneva, and a random stranger (Sean) helped me get the last leg back to where I am staying in Geneva. And I just love all those moments. I’m going solo tomorrow! Will send some posts here! 💕excited!
data.author: Cassandra Goldie
Cassandra Goldie

data.text: Fantastic! Yes, people are helpful! Enjoy your travels! I love cycling on my own.
data.author: Rhonda Klann Leduc

data.text: The biggest challenge is just running into a store to buy a drink with nobody there to guard your stuff.
data.author: Kerry Vanderzalm

data.text: It’s very easy when travelling solo to find a riding companion, it can then become very difficult getting rid of that riding companion if you need too!
data.author: Joe Francis

data.text: The biggest challenge is coping without my valet.
data.author: Bob Marshall

data.text: Absolutely brilliant. When riding solo you will meet more people and get invited into strangers homes for food. A bonus is that only person that will annoy you will be yourself.
data.author: David O'Donnell

data.text: Perfect way to travel
data.author: Heinrich Benz

data.text: Bring some ear buds or a radio to keep you entertained. You might be riding solo but Your gonna run into people along the way and have conversations anyways
data.author: Norbe Alatorre

data.text: Best
data.author: Viktor Spett

data.text: Solo is great when you tired you get some rest 😊 and you met many people and offers for meal and accomodation
data.author: Safaritour Tanzania Safari Tanzania

data.text: My name is Amina am from Tanzania east Africa hi everyone!
data.author: Safaritour Tanzania Safari Tanzania

data.text: I'm from Kenya
data.author: Ortiz

data.text: There’s always challenges…. that’s part of the fun and the appeal !
data.author: Craig Wehrli

data.text: Being alone for a long time. You start talking to the animals!😂
data.author: Roberto Hamar

data.text: I want to try it because when I'm with my friends I don't like it because my friends like cigarettes and I don't want cigarette smoke .. 😊🙏
data.author: Cubung Betoxrawa

data.text: I did my first tour solo and my husband has joined me for the rest. I only did a few nights of wild camping when I was on my own and didn't feel terribly comfortable. So that limits things things a bit. Being solo makes it a lot harder to quickly go into supermarkets or cathedrals or similar places where you don't want to completely unpack your bike yet you don't feel comfortable leaving it unattended. With two people you can take it in turns to do those things. I enjoyed my solo trip but I enjoy touring with my husband far more. Sharing the memories is priceless for us. We look at bicycle tour photos all through the year because it's one of the best things we do with our lives.
data.author: Cath Wood

data.text: great words I have loved touring with my wife. Although she now has MND and I will not last the year out. Then I have to try solo. Trying to prepare for it mentally.
data.author: Rod Lennon

data.text: Oh my heart breaks for you, I'm so very sorry to hear this. Your first solo tour will be an important time for you, I hope you have the freedom in your life to take as long as you need.
data.author: Cath Wood

data.text: thanks I do. Retiring soon. Pretty comfy for money and time.
data.author: Rod Lennon

data.text: well done, glad to hear it. Draw on the support of groups like this when the time comes.
data.author: Cath Wood

data.text: Love it
data.author: Mike Cook

data.text: It is soooper. I did 170 kms. Kochin. Back next day. Cheerful. All d best bro
data.author: Ali Sabry

data.text: Solo means you can't blame any one else
data.author: Marshall Innes

data.text: Solo is best
data.author: Blu Sky

data.text: But who took the photo 📸 😜 i am sure it was a passer by! Looks amazing, what a reward for all that climbing!!

data.text: I love your bike

data.text: exactly :) a passerby

data.text: it was all about 10,000 feet elevation..
data.author: Blu Sky

data.text: Go and face it yourself. Your and other people's will not be the same beacuse of terrains environment and many more so, just explore and you'll know.
data.author: Anzace Hanma

data.text: I have ridden solo from Jakarta to Denpasar. It was a great experience.
data.author: Serge Prytkin

data.text: In Vietnam the challenge was always having to explain why I was travelling solo. Not a thing in that culture. People kept telling me it was sad.

data.text: How far did you travel alone?
data.author: Ortiz

data.text: for about 2.5 months :)

data.text: You are a legend man. Camping or hoteling

data.text: First of all you should be physically fit and healthy

data.text: set off flabby and set easy challenges to start with. No need to wait or you'll never do it!

data.text: Very important
data.author: Ortiz

data.text: I’ve done about 25,000 km. of solo riding over the years. For me the biggest challenge is being away from family for so long.
data.author: Wayne Wood

data.text: Solo is fine but riding with someone is brilliant.
data.author: Sreten Živković

data.text: No
data.author: Francois Swanepoel

data.text: You get to pick where to go when you want to at your own speed.
data.author: Mike Dannheim

data.text: Fucking love it ...edgy stuff always , keep the adrenalin pumping
data.author: Nizzy Arief

data.text: Challenges? Only having to worry about my bike being outside of the grocery store and not being able to feasibly buy larger quantities of food. Otherwise, solo riding is the best
data.author: Benjamin Moravec
